'''Richard Johnston''' is an American [[country blues]] musician<ref name="Piltz">{{Citation| last = Piltz| first = Dave| title = CD Review: Richard Johnston Foothill Stomp| work = Blues on Stage| publisher = The Blues Foundation | date = November 2002| year = | url = http://www.mnblues.com/cdreview/2002/richardjohnston-foothill-dp.html| accessdate = 7 March 2010}}</ref> who won the 2001 [[International Blues Challenge]], and the 2001 [[Albert King]] Award for most promising blues guitarist.<ref>{{Citation| last = Gordon| first = Keith| title= Richard Johnston Interview|publisher=Blues.about.com|year = 2003|url= http://blues.about.com/od/bluesinterviews/a/RichJohnston.htm| accessdate=7 March 2010 }}</ref> His work as a [[Street performance|street musician]] on [[Beale Street]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]] was documented in the Alabama PBS film ''Richard Johnston: Hill Country Troubadour''. The film, directed by Max Shores, featured Johnston singing and playing his "Lowebow"<ref>[http://www.cigarboxguitars.com/features/Johnny_Lowe.php ]{{dead link|date=May 2014}}</ref> [[cigar box guitar]]. It won first place in the professional documentary film category at the 2007 George Lindsey/UNA Film Festival.

Johnston studied under blues artists including [[R.L. Burnside]], [[Junior Kimbrough]] and [[Jessie Mae Hemphill]]. His first album, ''Foot Hill Stomp'' (2002), featured Hemphill on vocals and tambourine, with assistance from R.L. Burnside's grandson, [[Cedric Burnside]], and others.<ref name="Piltz"/> 

His second album, ''Official Bootleg #1'' (2004), was assisted by Hemphill and by Cedric Burnside, and other artists.<ref>{{cite web|author=Bill Mitchell |url=http://www.bluenight.com/BluesBytes/wn0305.html |title=Blues Bytes What's New |publisher=Bluenight.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-18}}</ref>
